questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is a specific sign for Graves' disease?
questions.explanation:
Ophthalmopathy is the specific sign of Graves’ disease. Glycosaminoglycan deposition, lymphoid infiltrates and fatty infiltration are responsible for 
ophthalmopathy and dermopathy. Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder due to the production of TSH-receptor stimulating 
immunoglobulins (TSI) thereby causing hyperthyroidism. It is characterized by the triad of: • Thyrotoxicosis • Infiltrative ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos) • Dermopathy (pretibial myxedema) 104 
Sold by @itachibot Ophthalmopathy can sometimes precede or follow thyrotoxicosis, accounting for some cases of 
euthyroid ophthalmopathy.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient with Graves' disease presents with the following finding. Which statement regarding 
this condition is false?

options.a: Acropachy is strongly associated with this condition.
options.b: It occurs in more than 50% of patients with Graves' disease.
options.c: It occurs almost always in the presence of moderate or severe form of ophthalmopathy.
options.d: Skin changes can occur after trauma.

questions.explanation:
The given scenario along with the image is suggestive of thyroid dermopathy. It occurs in <5% 
of patients with Graves’ disease. Thyroid dermopathy is almost always associated with 
ophthalmopathy. Thyroid dermopathy is most frequently observed over the anterolateral parts of the lower leg. 
Hence, it is termed pretibial myxedema. Skin changes can occur at other sites, particularly after 
trauma. The typical lesion is a noninflamed, indurated plaque with a deep pink or purple color 
and orange peel-textured papules. Thyroid acropachy refers to a form of clubbing rarely observed in Graves’ disease. It is strongly 
associated with thyroid dermopathy. Thyroid dermopathy usually does not need any active treatment, but if necessary, treatment 
includes topical, high-potency glucocorticoid ointment under an occlusive dressing or octreotide 
can be useful in some cases. The following image shows thyroid dermopathy and acropachy:

Question 3: 98 
Sold by @itachibot A patient from a hilly area was referred with a partial small bowel obstruction confirmed on 
CECT. Conservative management was tried for a week, but he continued to deteriorate and 
was taken up for emergency laparotomy. On post-operative day 7, he developed atrial 
fibrillation. Investigations revealed elevated free T3 and free T4 levels. What is the most 
probable cause?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the Jod-Basedow phenomenon, likely due to the 
administration of an iodine-containing contrast agent during CECT. This phenomenon is characterized by hyperthyroidism due to enhanced thyroid hormone 
production following the administration of contrast agents and other iodine-containing 
substances. This occurs in: 105 
Sold by @itachibot • Patients with autonomous thyroid nodules • Patients with pre-existing subclinical hypothyroidism (endemic iodine deficiency in hilly areas) Option B: Wolff-Chaikoff effect is characterized by the transient inhibition of thyroid iodide 
organification by excess iodine, thereby decreasing thyroid hormone synthesis. Option C: Basedow disease is another name for Graves' disease. Option D: Plummer disease is another name for toxic multinodular goitre.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following statements is not true about thyroid storm?

options.a: Symptoms are vomiting, diarrhoea, jaundice and altered mentation
options.b: The mortality rate is 10% with treatment
options.d: High doses of propranolol decrease T4  T3 conversion

questions.explanation: The mortality rate of thyrotoxicosis crisis is almost 30% even with treatment. The usual causes for mortality are: • Cardiac failure • Arrhythmia • Hyperthermia

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following conditions is not associated with amiodarone therapy?
questions.explanation:
Silent thyroiditis is not associated with amiodarone therapy. Amiodarone has the following effects on the thyroid gland: 106 
Sold by @itachibot • Acute, transient suppression of thyroid function i.e., Wolff-Chaikoff effect • Hypothyroidism in patients susceptible to the inhibitory effects of a high iodine load • Thyrotoxicosis may be caused by Jod-Basedow phenomenon due to the iodine load, in the 
setting of multinodular goitre or incipient Graves’ disease. It can also be caused by a 
thyroiditis-like condition. Painless thyroiditis, or silent thyroiditis, occurs in patients with underlying autoimmune thyroid 
disease and has a clinical course similar to that of subacute thyroiditis. The condition can occur in up to 5% of women 3–6 months after pregnancy and is then termed 
postpartum thyroiditis.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following statements about amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis is false?

options.a: Type 2 AIT is associated with intrinsic abnormalities of the thyroid gland
options.b: Type 2 AIT is due to lysosomal destruction of thyroid gland.
options.c: Type 1 AIT is due to Jod-Basedow phenomenon.
options.d: Colour flow doppler shows increased vascularity in Type 1

questions.explanation:
Type 1 AIT is associated with intrinsic abnormalities of the thyroid gland. Amiodarone is structurally similar to thyroid hormones and contains 39% iodine by weight. 
Amiodarone-induced thyrotoxicosis (AIT) is the most common manifestation of the effects of 
amiodarone on the thyroid. Administration of amiodarone should be stopped if possible. Near-total thyroidectomy rapidly decreases thyroid hormone levels and may be the most effective

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following statements is true about non-toxic multinodular goitre?

options.a: It is more commonly observed in women
options.b: It does not occur in iodine-deficient regions
options.c: Most patients with non-toxic MNG have hypothyroidism
options.d: Risk of malignancy is higher than in cases of solitary thyroid nodule

questions.explanation:
Multinodular goitre (MNG) is more commonly observed in women. It is common in 
iodine-deficient regions. Most patients are asymptomatic and euthyroid. Sudden pain may occur due to haemorrhage. 
TFTs should be performed in all patients to exclude thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism. The risk of malignancy due to MNG is similar to that due to solitary nodules. Hoarseness, 
reflecting the involvement of laryngeal nerves implicate malignancy. Most non-toxic MNGs can be managed conservatively. Levothyroxine if used, should be started at 
low doses and then increased gradually. Radioiodine therapy is implemented for large goitres as it 107 
Sold by @itachibot decreases goitre size and can ablate regions of autonomy.

questions.question: Question 9: What is the major difference between non-toxic and toxic multinodular goitre?
questions.explanation:
The major difference between toxic and non-toxic multinodular goiter (MNG) is the presence of 
functional autonomy in toxic MNG. The pathogenesis of toxic MNG appears to be similar to that of non-toxic MNG. In both types, 
many nodules are polyclonal whereas others are monoclonal and vary in their clonal origins. Most patients with non-toxic MNG are asymptomatic and euthyroid. However, patients with toxic 
MNG have subclinical or mild hyperthyroidism.

Question 11: 100 
Sold by @itachibot The following patients presented with thyroid nodules. Who has the least risk of developing 
thyroid carcinoma?

options.a: A 55-year-old woman with no voice abnormalities and nodule size of 3 cms
options.b: A 65-year-old woman with vocal cord paralysis and hoarse voice and nodule size of 3.5 cms
options.c: A 60-year-old man without any voice abnormalities and nodule size of 2.5 cms
options.d: A 43-year-old woman with no voice abnormalities and nodule size of 4.5 cm

questions.explanation:
Among the options, the female patient with age between 20 and 65 years and no voice 
abnormalities and nodule size < 4 cm has the least risk for development of thyroid carcinoma. Risk factors for the development of thyroid carcinoma in patients with thyroid nodules include: • Age less than 20 or greater than 65 years • Male gender • Increased nodule size > 4 cm • Vocal cord paralysis and hoarse voice • New or enlarged neck mass • Family history of thyroid cancer, MEN2, or other syndromes associated with thyroid malignancy 
(e.g., Cowden’s syndrome, familial polyposis, Carney complex) 108 
Sold by @itachibot • Nodule fixed to adjacent structures • Exposure to radiation in childhood or adolescence • Extrathyroidal extension • Lateral cervical lymphadenopathy

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following statements is not true about thyroid hormone resistance?

options.a: Inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
options.b: Characterized by elevated thyroid hormone levels and normal or elevated TSH
options.c: Classic forms are caused by mutations in TR- gene

questions.explanation:
Thyroid hormone resistance is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is characterized by elevated thyroid hormone levels and inappropriately elevated or normal TSH 
levels. Classic forms of the disease are attributed to the mutation in TR- gene. Patients with this 
condition are often asymptomatic, as hormone resistance is partial and compensated by the 
increase in thyroid hormone levels. In most patients, no treatment is indicated.

questions.question: Question 13: Patients with what condition present with normal thyroglobulin levels?
questions.explanation:
Serum thyroglobulin levels are normal in patients with thyrotoxicosis factitia, as it is caused by 
the self-administration of thyroid hormone. Its level is elevated in all other types of thyrotoxicosis. Thyroglobulin (Tg) levels are particularly increased in thyroiditis, implicating destruction of 
thyroid tissue and release of thyroglobulin. The primary course of action for determining the thyroglobulin levels, however, is in the 
clinical follow-up of thyroid cancer patients. Following total thyroidectomy and radiofrequency ablation, thyroglobulin levels become 
undetectable. In the absence of anti-Tg antibodies, measurable levels of Tg are indicative of 
incomplete ablation or recurrent cancer.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient presented with fever and painful neck swelling. She gives a history of sore throat 
and cough one week ago. Lab investigations revealed elevated T3 and T4 levels and elevated 
ESR. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

options.a: Treatment of choice is supportive care and NSAIDs
options.b: Women are generally affected three times more often than men
options.c: Both thyrotoxic and hypothyroid phases can be observed

questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of De Quervain’s thyroiditis, and it is not autoimmune in origin. 
It is subacute granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral infections. Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been 
clinically implicated in this condition. Peak incidence is observed at 30-50 years and women are 
generally affected three times more often than men. Clinically, it presents as a painfully enlarged thyroid and is sometimes accompanied by fever. It has three distinct phases: • Thyrotoxic phase 109 
Sold by @itachibot • Hypothyroid phase • Recovery phase Treatment includes large doses of aspirin, NSAIDs, steroids and/or beta-blockers to relieve the 
observable clinical symptoms. Antithyroid drugs do not have any role. In case the hypothyroid 
phase is prolonged - levothyroxine can be used.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following conditions is not associated with hypothyroidism?
questions.explanation: Graves' disease is not associated with hypothyroidism.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 4-month-old baby presented with a history of constipation, lethargy, and has poor 
activities. Clinical examination reveals jaundice, hypotonia and there was no palpable goitre. 
Laboratory investigations revealed low T4 and elevated TSH levels. Which of the following is 
not true about this condition?

options.a: Most common cause is inborn defects in the synthesis of thyroid hormone
options.b: The developmental abnormalities are more common in girls
options.d: High circulating T4 level is needed to normalize TSH

questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism. The most common cause of this 
condition is thyroid gland dysgenesis, seen in about 80-85% of cases of neonatal hypothyroidism. In the remaining cases of neonatal hypothyroidism, it is due to inborn defects in thyroid hormone 
synthesis and rarely due to TSH receptor antibodies. These developmental abnormalities are twice 
as common in girls. Clinical features include: • Prolonged jaundice • Umbilical hernia • Enlarged tongue • Hypotonia • Delayed bone maturation Permanent neurological damage results if treatment is delayed. T4 requirements are relatively high during the first year of life. A high circulating T4 level is 
needed to normalize TSH. Early treatment with T4 results in normal IQ levels by preventing neurodevelopmental 
abnormalities.

questions.question: Question 17: Patients with autoimmune hypothyroidism have a higher predisposition for all except:
questions.explanation:
Autoimmune hypothyroidism is usually not associated with type II diabetes mellitus. Genetic risk factors for autoimmune hypothyroidism has been documented with HLA-DR3, 
HLA-DR4, HLA-DR5. A weak association also exists with CTLA4 gene polymorphism. This may explain the relationship between autoimmune hypothyroidism and type I diabetes 
mellitus, Addison's disease, pernicious anemia, and vitiligo. 110 
Sold by @itachibot Less commonly encountered clinical associations include: • Celiac disease • Dermatitis herpetiformis • Chronic active hepatitis • Rheumatoid arthritis • Myasthenia gravis • Systemic lupus erythematosus • Sjogren's syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 19: An elderly patient presents to the ER with symptoms suggestive of myxedema coma. Which 
of the following is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Hyperthermia is least likely in this patient. Clinical manifestations of myxedema coma include 
decreased consciousness, seizures and hypothermia. Myxedema coma is a serious condition with a mortality rate of 20-40%. The clinical outcomes are 
independent of the detected T4 and TSH levels. Clinical features of myxedema crisis include: • Impaired cognition, ranging from confusion to somnolence to coma (myxedema coma) • Convulsions and abnormal CNS signs. • Profound hypothermia (can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, 
hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension. • Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury. 111 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. 
Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the ■administration of 
TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient?

options.a: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
options.b: Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
options.c: Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
options.d: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.explanation:
The presenting symptoms of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain are suggestive of 
hypothyroidism. An increase in TSH on administration of TRH confirms the lack of stimulus for 
TSH secretion from the hypothalamus. Although decreased TSH levels can be seen in hyperthyroidism, clinical features such as lethargy, 
increased sleep and weight gain are not. This pushes the diagnosis in favor of hypothyroidism. If the disease was in the pituitary, there would be no increase in TSH secretion on administration 
of TRH (Option B). Normally, the thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) is released by the hypothalamus. It 
stimulates the pituitary gland to release the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), which in turn 
stimulates the thyroid gland to produce T3 and T4 hormones. Low TSH levels may be seen in the following cases: Disease

questions.question:
Question 21: A middle-aged woman with a history of constipation, dry skin and menorrhagia presents to 
the ER with altered sensorium, non-pitting edema, hypothermia, bradycardia, and 
hypotension. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical history is typical of a case of hypothyroidism and the diagnosis is myxedema 
coma, which is a serious complication of hypothyroidism. Myxedema coma is a part of a larger clinical picture of myxedema crisis. Myxedema crisis refers to 
severe, life-threatening manifestations of hypothyroidism. It is often precipitated by the 
administration of sedatives, antidepressants, hypnotics, anaesthetics, or opioids. Clinical features of myxedema crisis : • Impaired cognition, ranging from confusion to somnolence to coma (myxedema coma). • Convulsions and abnormal CNS signs. • Profound hypothermia (can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, 
hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension. • Rhabdomyolysis and acute kidney injury • A high mortality rate Other options: Option A: Without a history of or focus of infection, septic shock is unlikely. Option B: Cardiogenic shock would present with symptoms of left heart failure i.e. pitting pedal 
edema, abdominal distension, prominence of neck veins, and dyspnea. Option D: Hypoglycemia usually presents with sweating, palpitations, and tachycardia 113 
Sold by @itachibot Thyroid Disorders - Management
